**PATIENT INFORMATION:**
- Name: Thomas Bradford
- MRN: [REDACTED]
- DOB: [REDACTED]
- Date of Procedure: [REDACTED]
- Procedure Time: 13:15-14:05

**INSTITUTION:[REDACTED]

**ATTENDING PHYSICIAN:** Dr. Andrew Sullivan, MD, FCCP (Interventional Pulmonology)

**INDICATION:**
79-year-old male with metastatic mesothelioma and refractory left malignant pleural effusion. Patient has undergone multiple thoracenteses with rapid reaccumulation (7-10 days). Patient declining aggressive interventions, focusing on symptom management and quality of life.

**PRE-PROCEDURE:**
- Goals of care discussion held with patient and family
- Informed consent obtained with emphasis on palliative intent
- Timeout performed
- Bedside ultrasound: Large left pleural effusion, maximum depth 12.5 cm, complex with multiple thin septations
- Chest CT reviewed: Pleural thickening and nodularity consistent with known mesothelioma
- Cardiopulmonary status optimized
- Vital signs: BP 142/84, HR 92, SpO2 88% on 4L NC

**PROCEDURE DETAILS:**
- Patient positioned in right lateral decubitus position with support
- Left lateral chest, 6th intercostal space, mid-axillary line
- Site id[REDACTED] avoiding areas of dense pleural disease
- Chlorhexidine skin preparation, sterile draping
- Local anesthesia: 20 mL 1% lidocaine (patient also received 2 mg IV midazolam for anxiolysis)
- Small incision made
- Subcutaneous tunnel created (7 cm)
- 15.5 French PleurX catheter advanced under ultrasound guidance, avoiding septations
- Wire and catheter passed without resistance
- Catheter secured with non-absorbable suture
- Dacron cuff positioned appropriately
- Drainage initiated: 950 mL serosanguinous fluid removed initially
- Patient developed mild cough, drainage temporarily paused then resumed
- Total drainage: 1,200 mL

**CATHETER SPECIFICATIONS:**
- Type: PleurX drainage catheter
- French Size: 15.5 Fr

**SPECIMENS SENT:**
- None (diagnosis already established)

**POST-PROCEDURE:**
- Procedure completed without major complications
- Portable chest X-ray: IPC in place, moderate residual effusion, no pneumothorax
- Patient experienced transient pleuritic pain (6/10), responded to IV fentanyl 50 mcg
- Dressing applied
- Patient and daughter educated on drainage procedure
- Hospice agency contacted for coordination of care and drainage assistance
- Vital signs: BP 138/82, HR 88, SpO2 92% on 4L NC
- Patient reports improved breathing despite residual effusion

**COMPLICATIONS:** Minor - transient pleuritic pain post-procedure, resolved with analgesics

**ASSESSMENT:** Successful placement of left indwelling pleural catheter for palliative management of malignant pleural effusion secondary to mesothelioma. Given septations and extensive pleural disease, spontaneous pleurodesis unlikely.

**PLAN:**
- Drainage schedule: As needed for symptoms, typically every 2-3 days
- Hospice nursing to manage catheter drainage and site care
- Focus on symptom management and quality of life
- Patient instructed to report fever, increasing pain, or catheter dysfunction
- Avoid aggressive drainage goals given palliative intent
- Outpatient follow-up PRN
- Continue palliative care coordination
